review.potassium: Low - flattened [blr]T waves[/blr], prominent [blr]U waves[/blr], [blr]ST-[/blr]segment [blr]depression[/blr], prolonged [blr]PR interval[/blr],

review.statin: Must be given at night when [blr]cholesterol[/blr] production is highest

Are the reminaing answers referring to airway, breathing or circulation (ABCs)? Eliminate each non-priority answer option using the ABCs. Are the reminaing asnwer options real (actual) or potential problems? Eliminate the potential problem answer options.
review.systemic-lupus-erythematosus: [blr]Malar[/blr] rash - rash extending across the nasal bridge and upper cheeks.

review.right-sided-heart-failure: Congestion of the [blr]gastric[/blr] veins, resulting in anorexia and eventual development of ascites

review.fluid-intake: Normal fluid intake should be between [blr]1,500 - 2,000[/blr] ml/day

review.low-hemoglobin: First apply [blr]oxygen[/blr] to make sure the available hemoglobin is well [blr]oxygenated[/blr], place [blr]on cardiac monitor[/blr], start the [blr]intravenous catheter[/blr], [blr]draw the blood work[/blr].

review.corticosteroid: Increases levels of [blr]glucose[/blr], increases [blr]sodium[/blr] levels, decreases [blr]potassium[/blr] and [blr]calcium[/blr] levels

review.alzheimer: Reduced [blr]anxiety[/blr] first then reorient the client. Reduce anxiety by staying with the client and [blr]explaining[/blr] the environment. Clients may be calmer in the [blr]morning[/blr] and get more agitated as the day progresses.

review.chronic-alcohol-abuse: Hypomagnesemia - [blr]trermors[/blr], [blr]confusion[/blr], [blr]racing[/blr] heart - could be dangerous is severe.

review.systemic-inflammatory-response-syndrome: Caused by [blr]mechanical[/blr] tissue trauma and tissue [blr]ischemia[/blr], could lead to [blr]multi organ failure[/blr] Release of [blr]inflammatory markers[/blr], activation of [blr]coagulation cascade[/blr], decreased [blr]perfusion[/blr] and [blr]hypotension[/blr]
review.anorexia-nervosa: Refusal to eat for the fear of gaining weight. Increased [blr]BUN[/blr] due to lower blood volume ([blr]hyperuricemia[/blr])
review.disease-prevention: primary - [blr]preventing the disease[/blr] secondary - [blr]early detection[/blr] teriary - [blr]limit disease progression[/blr]
review.retroperitoneal-bleeding: Discoloration around the [blr]umbilicus[/blr] ([blr]Cullen's[/blr] sign) or flank ([blr]Grey Turner's[/blr] sign) [blr]Abdominal[/blr] pain or numbness of [blr]lower extremities[/blr] (due to [blr])spinal nerve compression[/blr]) [blr]Volume replacement[/blr] is the priority using [blr]colloid[/blr] or [blr]crystalloid[/blr] solutions
review.vasopressin: Should replace [blr]fluid[/blr] first before adminstration of [blr]vasopressin[/blr]
review.neuroleptic-malignant-syndrome: Complication resulting from [blr]antipsychotic[/blr] medications Could occur even with one dose of [blr]medication[/blr], therefore must always monitor [blr]temperature[/blr] when administering antipsychotics
review.escherichia-coli: Does not need [blr]contact[/blr] precautions unless the client is [blr]incontinent[/blr] or is [blr]wearing a diaper[/blr].
review.glomerulonephritis: Causes an elevated [blr]serum anti-streptolysin o (ASO)[/blr] titer
review.psoriasis: Presents as [blr]white[/blr], [blr]silvery[/blr], [blr]scaly[/blr] patches on the skin Most common areas are [blr]elbows[/blr], [blr]knees[/blr], [blr]scalp[/blr] and [blr]scrotum[/blr]
review.radiation-safety: Visitation no more than [blr]30 min[/blr] Distance no less than [blr]6[/blr] feet No [blr]pregnant[/blr] staff or visitors
review.myelomeningocele: [blr]Cover with moist dressing[/blr] Take great care to avoid rupture, as CNS [blr]infection[/blr] would be imminent Surgery done [blr]24-48[/blr] hours after birth
review.gun-safety: Store [blr]ammunition[/blr] separately from guns Guns should never be stored [blr]loaded[/blr]
review.deep-tendon-reflexes: Rated on a 4 point scale 0 - no response 1 - slight, but definitive response 2 - brisk; normal 3 - very brisk 4 - overactive - abnormal
review.respiratory-rate: Normal is [blr]12[/blr] and higher per minute
review.magnesium: Acts as a [blr]smooth muscle relaxer[/blr], resulsts in [blr]vasodialtion[/blr] and [blr]reduced blood pressure[/blr] Normal levels [blr]1.3 - 2.1[/blr] mEq/L
review.Addisons-disease: Hyposecrion of [blr]adrenal hormones[/blr] Causes [blr]hyponatremia[/blr], [blr]hypotension[/blr], [blr]fatigue[/blr] and muscle cramps [blr]Hyperkalemia[/blr] due to decreased [blr]potassium[/blr] release Could result in [blr]hypercalcemia[/blr] [blr]Tanned[/blr] skin without [blr]sun exposure[/blr] [blr]Hairloss[/blr] due to reduced [blr]androgen[/blr] levels, especially in [blr]females[/blr] because [blr]adrenal glands[/blr] produce most [blr]androgens[/blr] in females [blr]Hypoglycemia[/blr] due to reduction of cortisol [blr]Gastric acid[/blr] production decreases
review.Hyperkalemia: Promotes reabsorption of [blr]hydrogen ions[/blr], leading to [blr]acidosis[/blr].
review.aldosterone: Main [blr]mineralcorticoid[/blr] produced by the [blr]zona glomerulosa[/blr] of the adrenal gland Essential for [blr]sodium[/blr] conservation
review.oral-contraceptives: Suppress the production of [blr]breastmilk[/blr], if the client is [blr]breastfeeind[/blr] other methods of [blr]contraception[/blr] should be used.
review.glaucoma: If the pressure readings are [blr]borderline[/blr], pressure should be take at [blr]multiple points throughout the day[/blr]. Secondary glaucoma could be caused by [blr]neurovasuclar[/blr] disorders, such as [blr]CVAs[/blr]. Vision loss occurs in [blr]peripheral[/blr] vision initially. Open-Angle - affects [blr]both eyes simultaneously[/blr], [blr]slow[/blr] progression Closed-Angle - usually affects [blr]one eye at a time[/blr]. More common in [blr]black race[/blr] - [blr]six[/blr] fold incrase Other risk factors include being [blr]higly far sighted[/blr].
review.colorectal-cancer: Risk factors - [blr]African American[/blr], BMI > [blr]30[/blr], [blr]smoking[/blr], alcohol consumption [blr]> 4[/blr] drinks per week, red meat [blr]> 7[/blr] servings per week, relatives with the disease When considering who is at higher risk, count the risk factors
review.fall: Complete a physical assessment of the client to make sure they didn't sustain any injuries, if they didn't: fill out [blr]an incident report[/blr] then [blr]call the provider[/blr], then [blr]call the family[/blr].
review.leukocytes: Normal levels are between [blr] 4.5 - 11,000 [/blr] units per microliter.
review.hyponatremia: Body compensates for low sodium by retaining [blr]lithium[/blr].
review.tuberculin-skin-test: Administration of a [blr]live-virus-vaccine[/blr] may cause a false [blr]negative[/blr] on a TST. If administering a [blr]live virus vaccine[/blr] it should be done [blr]on the same day[/blr] as the TST or waiting [blr]4-6 weeks[/blr] after a live vaccine. False negative could also occur due to a [blr]weakened immune system[/blr]. [blr]Bacille Calmette-Guerin (vaccine)[/blr] could give a false positive if given within [blr]4-6 weeks[/blr] of TST.
review.corticosteroid: Suppress the [blr]immune system[/blr] and could give a false negative on [blr]tuberculin-skin-test[/blr].
review.acquired-immondeficinecy-syndrome: Could produce a false negative on a [blr]tuberculin-skin-test[/blr] due to immune system supresssion.
review.tuberculosis: A diagnosis is confirmed when [blr]a sputum sample is cultured.[/blr]
review.live-virus-vaccine: Vaccines for [blr]herpes zoster (shingles)[/blr], [blr]measles[/blr] vaccine and [blr]mumps[/blr] vaccine.
review.peripherally-inserted-central-catheter: In case the catheter breaks, [blr]tourniquet the arm by the shoulder[/blr] - then check to make sure the arm still has a [blr]radial pulse[/blr] (don't want to [blr]complete occlude the blood flow[/blr]), then order [blr]an x-ray[/blr]. Do not [blr]move[/blr] the client to prevent [blr]movement[/blr] of the catheter piece.
review.dysphagia: Level 1 - [blr]pureed[/blr] foods, need no [blr]chewing[/blr]. Level 2 - [blr]mechanically altered foods, moist foods that needs some chewing.[/blr] Examples are [blr]meatloaf[/blr] with [blr]mash[/blr] and [blr]gravy[/blr]. Meats should be [blr]ground[/blr] and [blr]gravies[/blr] are used to soften. Level 3 - [blr]advanced[/blr] diet, [blr]soft solid[/blr] foods need more [blr]chewing[/blr]. Example would be [blr]pasta[/blr], [blr]thinly sliced[/blr] chicken. Exclude foods that are [blr]tough[/blr], [blr]cruncy[/blr] or [blr]sticky[/blr]. Level 4 - [blr]general[/blr] diet, [blr]all foods[/blr] included.
review.diabetes-insipidus: Characterized by a decrease in [blr]anti-diuretic-hormone[/blr]. Causes increased [blr]urine output[/blr] and increased [blr]sodium[/blr] concentrations. Excretion of dilute urine at [blr]200 ml/hr[/blr] +
review.access-port: Should be scrubbed for [blr]30-60[/blr] seconds prior to use.
review.abuse: Risk factors for older adults: [blr]female[/blr], reduced [blr]social interaction[/blr], at least [blr]one physical or mental impairment[/blr].
review.fetal-heart-rate: Should be heard with a [blr]doppler[/blr] at [blr]10-12[/blr] weeks.
review.ballotment: Movement of the fetus that is palpated with a [blr]tap on the uterus[/blr]. Should be first felt at [blr]4-5[/blr] months.
review.gentamycin: An [blr]aminoglycoside[/blr] antibiotic. Treats infections caused by [blr]pseudomonas aeruginosa[/blr], [blr]Escherichia-coli[/blr] and [blr]staphylococcus[/blr].
review.straight-catherterization: In home setting: no need for [blr]sterile procedures[/blr], catheters are [blr]reused[/blr] after [blr]washing[/blr] them with [blr]anti-bacterial soap[/blr] and [blr]povidone-iodine[/blr].
review.right-hemisphere: Responsible for identifying [blr]person[/blr], [blr]place[/blr] and [blr]times[/blr]. Responsible for controlling [blr]impulsive behaviour[/blr].
review.chronic-kidney-disease: Diet needs to be low in [blr]protein[/blr], [blr]sodium[/blr], [blr]potassium[/blr] and [blr]phosphorus[/blr].
review.hypoglycemia: Blood glucose less than [blr]60mg/dL[/blr] Treatments when concious - [blr]15-20g[/blr] of rapid acting sugars such as [blr] 4oz[/blr] of [blr]fruit juice[/blr] or [blr]soda[/blr], [blr]8 oz[/blr] of [blr]milk[/blr], [blr]tablespoon[/blr] of [blr]sugar[/blr] Treatments when semiconcious - [blr]1mg[/blr] of [blr]glucagon[/blr] administered [blr]IM[/blr] or [blr]SC[/blr] or [blr]25-50[/blr] mg [blr]50%[/blr] of [blr]dextrose[/blr] administered [blr]IV[/blr].
review.macular-degeneration: After surgery the client has to remain [blr]face down[/blr].
review.cataract: After surgery: avoid [blr]activitives[/blr] that [blr]increase IOP[/blr] such as [blr]bending[/blr] or [blr]lifting heavy equipment[/blr] (more than [blr]10-15lbs[/blr])
review.liver-failure: Decrease [blr]fat[/blr] in diet, incrase [blr]calories[/blr], increase [blr]carbs[/blr], decrease [blr]sodium[/blr], decrease fluids to manage [blr]ascites[/blr]. [blr]Protein[/blr] should be lowered if [blr]ammonia[/blr] is high or should be raised if it's not.
review.Jackson-Pratt-drain: To remove: release [blr]the suction[/blr], remove [blr]sutures[/blr], ask patient to [blr]breath deeply[/blr] and [blr]regularly[/blr], pull drain out [blr]in one motion[/blr], assess the [blr]exit site[/blr] and cover it with [blr]gauze[/blr].
review.sterile-field: Keep hands at or above [blr]table level[/blr] [blr]1in[/blr] edge of the sterile field is non sterile and could only be touched with [blr]clean golve[/blr] (not [blr]sterile glove[/blr])
review.peripherally-inserted-central-catheter: Clean around the [blr]catheter[/blr] in [blr]circular motion[/blr] and [blr]away[/blr]. Dressing changes require [blr]sterile technique[/blr] Old dressing should be removed [blr]toward the[/blr] insertion site. Change [blr]gloves[/blr] after removing the [blr]old dressing[/blr].
review.continuous-renal-replacement-therapy: Indications: patients who have [blr]cardiovascular[/blr] impartments that can't tolerate [blr]low BP[/blr] that accompanies hemodialysis. [blr]Slow[/blr], continuous filtering of the blood. Does not require a [blr]av fistula[/blr], blood is drawn from [blr]femoral[/blr] or [blr]subcalvian[/blr] vein. Hemofilter should be changed every [blr]24-48[/blr] hours Clients are prone to [blr]hypothermia[/blr]
review.Jaundice: Best places to assesss for jaundice are [blr]abdomen skin[/blr], [blr]sclera of the eyes[/blr] and [blr]hard pallete[/blr]. In Asian-American populations, skin may have a natural yellow tone so the best place to assess for jaundice in this populace is the [blr]hard pallete[/blr].
review.LPN-delegation: [blr]Stable[/blr] clients. Cannot delegate [blr]teaching[/blr] or tasks that require [blr]assessment[/blr].
review.syndrome-of-inappropriate-antidiuretic-h: Causes the body to [blr]retain too much water[/blr]. [blr]Dilutional hyponatremia[/blr] occurs. Hypervolemia causes [blr]tachycardia[/blr]. Treatment includes restricting fluid intake to [blr]500-600[/blr]ml/[blr]24h[/blr], [blr]diuretics[/blr], [blr]daily weights[/blr] and strict [blr]intake and output[/blr]. End result is seizures and brain swelling.
review.newborn-facial-paralysis: Occurs because of compression of cranial nerve [blr]VII[/blr], usually resolves in [blr]a few days[/blr] to [blr]3 weeks[/blr], or [blr]could be permanent[/blr].
review.neonatal-red-reflex: Should be present in [blr]both eyes[/blr] and should be [blr]symmetrical[/blr]. If not present or not [blr]symmetrical[/blr] it is considered an [blr]opthalmic emergency[/blr]. Absense could cause [blr]blindness[/blr] if not treated right away.
review.sterile-field: Situations where sterile field is required: [blr]dialysis catheters[/blr], [blr]chest tube[/blr] insertion, inserting [blr]central venous[/blr] or [blr]arterial[/blr] lines, inserting [blr]drainage[/blr] devices.
review.iliostomy: If constipated then [blr]massage around the stoma[/blr] promoting [blr]peristalsis[/blr], drink [blr]warm fluids[/blr] they promote [blr]peristalsis[/blr] and provide a mild [blr]cathartic effect[/blr], take a [blr]warm shower[/blr] which helps promote [blr]abdominal muscle relaxation[/blr]
review.constipation: Drink [blr]warm fluids[/blr] they promote peristalsis and provide a mild [blr]cathartic effect[/blr], take a [blr]warm shower[/blr] which helps promote [blr]abdominal muscle relaxation[/blr]
review.dehydration: Drink a solution high in [blr]sodium[/blr] and [blr]potassium[/blr].
review.cyanosis: In dark skinned clinets assesed on [blr]light skin areas[/blr] such as the [blr]soles of feet[/blr] and [blr]palms of hands[/blr], oral cavity membranes and conjunctiva with bluish or light gray color.
review.post-traumatic-stress-disorder: Tendancy for violence and suicide. Allow talk of traumatic event. Teach about conditioning. Remove weapons from space.
review.diphenhydramine: Has anticholinergic properties. Contraindicated in closed angle glaucoma, small bowel obstruction - may increase obstruction, and peptic ulcers as it may increase bleeding.
review.status-epilepticus: Tonic-clonic (tonic - extension of arms/legs, clonic - contraction of arms and legs) should not last more than 60-90 seconds. Status epilepticus is established if there is a seizure followed by small rest then followed by another sezure or a seizure that lasts more than 5 minutes. Benzodiazapeines like diazapam are presricbed as they increase the seizure threshold in the brain. Given IV push, rectally or nasaly.
review.seizure: Lay on side so saliva can drain. Give oxygen if there are color changes. Lower clinet to floor, protect the head, clear objects from area. Administer Lore/diazepam. Stay with the client until alert.
review.Hodgekin-lymphoma: Painless swelling of cervical lymph node, usually single. The lymph node is usually freely movable, firm and painless. Ingestion of alcohol may result in the pain of the diseased lymph node.
review.post-anasthesia-care-unit: Priority is to maintain ABCs upon reiceval, second priority to monitor the incision site, third is giving presribed meds.
review.urinalysis: The sample does not need to be sterile. If obtaining from a catheter, use sterile technique to not introduce infection into the catheter, but the sample itself doens't need to be sterile.
review.tardive-dyskinesia: Characterized by abnormal facial or tongue movements. Treated by decreasing or discontinuing antipsychotic medication. Symptoms may reverse however may be permanent as well.
review.pseudoparkinsonism: Symptoms that mimic Parkinson's syndrome such as shuffling gait, tremors and rigidity. Treated with anticholinergics.
review.acute-dystonic-reaction: Caused by too much cholinergic neurotransmitters compared to dopaminergic ones. Contraction of facial and neck muscles, treated with diphenhydramine or benzotropine. Symtpoms improve after 10-30 min after administering IV anticholinergics.
review.neuroleptic-malignant-syndrome: Life threatening reaction that is lethal in 10% of cases. Stop the medication. Cool the body, administer bromocriptine to treat muscle regidity, dantrolene to reduce muscle spasms.
review.dantrolene: Used for muscle spasms, and it coudld be used for malignant hypothermia.
review.infant: Ages below 1 year. Erikson - Trust vs Mistrust
review.toddler:
Ages 1 - 3 Erikson - Autonomy vs Shame and Doubt Speaks in segments of 3-4 words. Able to express likes and dislikes. Assertion of independence Understand cuasality.
Encourage parents: postive reinforcement, give simple rationals, provide two selections for choice Communication: 12months - gestures (pointing, waving), follows one step commands, single words. 24 months - repeats words and phrases (echolalia), combines 2-3 words together, impulsive (tantrums), vocabulary of 40-50 words. 36 months - multiple words into pharases, verbalizes name, age and gender. Short conversations, follow 3 step commands, vocabulary of 200-1000 words.
review.pre-schooler: Ages 3 - 5 Erikson - Initiative vs Guilt Uses complete sentences. Could perform simple chores like putting away toys, or bringing items to the table. Understands right from wrong.
review.teenager: Ages 13-21 Erikson - Identity vs Role Confusion
review.detached-retina:
Symptoms: floaters across field of vision, blurred vision, black curtain over visual field Surgery: scleral buckling or laser photocoagulation
Post operatively: Limit eye movement of both eyes (even with suregery on one eye), bed rest with eye patch over operated eye. May require special positioning to maintain intravitreal bubble. Give eye drops - antibiotics, antiinflammatory and dilating agenets.
review.lactulose: Traps and expells ammonia from the blood via the feces. Results in soft formed stools. Also used as a laxative.
review.doppler-ultrasound: Probe held at 45 degrees. Probe should be held lightly as to not obliterate the pulse. If movement is performed move distal to proximal. Gel should be warm to reduce vasoconstriction.
review.pulse-deficit: Difference between apical and peripheral pulses.
review.thiazide-diuretics: Examples: Chlorothiazide, hydrochlorothiazide, indapamide, chlorthalidone, metolazone. Act directly on the kidney to inhibit the sodium/chloride cotransporter - which has a function of reabsorbing sodium and chloride ions in distal convoluted tubule. Increase sodium secretion. Increase potassium secretion. Decrease calcium secretion, thereby increasing serum calcium. Promotes alkalosis by increasing the release of hydrogen through urine.
review.electro-convulsive-therapy: Good candidate: pregnant, suicidal or catatonic, major depression, bipolar mania and schitzophrenia. Contraindications: cardiac problems, osteoporosis, loose teeth. 2-3 tretments per week for a month or 6-12 sessions total Performed under anesthesia
review.central-line-associated-bloodstream-infe: In order to get accurate cultures, first collect blood cultures from two separate peripheral sites then begin empiric antibiotic therapy with broad spectrum AB right away without waiting for cultures to return.
review.non-tunneled-central-venous-access-devic: Used for a short term, in acute care settings. Insertion procedure: Full sterile field with gowns, caps and masks and patient is covered with full body sterile drapes. Patient is placed in Trandelenburg position (head down) to contain air emboli in lower chambers and to produce dilation of neck and subclavian veins. Subclavian vein is used most of the time. Sometimes basilic, cephalic or as a last resort femoral veins could be used. Area is swabbed with chlorhexidine to remove any residual oils. Patient is asked to turn head away from insertion site to give more tension. Lidocaine is injected into tissue to numb the area. Large bore needle is insertered parallel to the clavicle and guided deeper until it hits the vein. Patient is asked to take a deep breath and perform the Valsalva manuver, that is bear down, to create a positive pressure phase in central venous pressure and make it harder for air emboli to move in, as the cather is guided through the needle and into the superior vena cava. Needle is removed and catheter is sutured to the skin. Chlorhexidine impregnated gauze with transparent dressing is placed over the insertion site. Catheter placement is confirmed with an x-ray (as well as to rule out accidental puncture of the pleura and pneumothorax)
review.Addisons-disease: Autoimmune disorders that results in destruction of adrenal glands. All three corticoids are reduced: glucocorticoids (cortisol), mineralcorticoids (aldosterone), and androgens. Lifelong steroid homrones given, doses should be increased during stresses like surgery. Salt is added to the diet. Potassium is usually elevated.
review.Addisonian-crisis: Due to rapid withdrawl of corticosteroid medication, or stress factors. Symptoms: hypotension, tachycardia, electrolyte imbalances. Can lead to shock and circulatory collapse.
review.adrenal-gland: Zona glomerulose - produces mineralcorticoids - example aldosterone Zona fasciculada - produces glucocorticoids - example cortisol Zona reticularis - produces androgens Medulla - produces catecholamines - epinephrine and norepinephrine
review.lactation: Need to add 400-500 cal daily to pre-pregnancy caloric intake to compensate for breasfeeding.
review.multiple-sclerosis: Avoid overexposure to heat or cold - may damage areas that have lost sensation. May also excerbate MS symptoms.
review.Paget-disease: Interferes with bone remodeling, causes enlarged skull, curving of leg bones, bones become weaker. Elevated serum alkaline phosphatase (ALP). Treated with same medications as osteoporosis (that is biphosphonates).
review.overdose: Check for responsiveness and breathing rate - if none begin CPR Call for nearby help Have someone call 911 Have someone get AED Have someone get nalaxone
review.opioid-withdrawl: Symptoms: shivering, abdominal cramping, muscle and bone pain, vomiting, diarrhea.
review.GTPAL: Gravida - number of pregnancies (twins or more count as one) Term - number of deliveries of 38 weeks + (twins or more count as one) Preterm - number of deliveries 20 - 37 weeks (twins or more count as one) Abortions - number of pregnancies ending prior to 20 weeks (including spontaneously) (twins or more count as 1) Living - number of living children
review.gravida-parity: Only uses two numbers Gravida - number of pregnancies (twins or more count as one) Parity - number of pregnancies carried past 20 weeks, including pregncies that eneded in spontaneous abortion. (Also counts multiple embryos as one)
review.intestinal-secretions: Hihgh in bicarbonate, loss of which (like in iliostomys) leads to metabolic acidosis
review.metabolic-acidosis: Associated with hyperkalemia, Kussmaul respirations (deep rapid breathing to rid body of CO2) and tachycardia.
review.eating-disorders: Observe the client before, during and after meals. Avoid discussions about food especially while eating. Require food consumption within limited amount of time. Feed through an NG tube if required.
review.Haemophilus-influenzae: Leading cause of bacterial meningitis in children under 5 years old. Could also cause pneumonia, sepsis and death.
review.delivery-instructions: Panting through the mouth helps prevent immediate delivery. Confirm that the neonate doesn't have a cord around the neck before proceeding with delivery. If cord is detected slip two fingers between the cord and the neonate to give space for breathing and continue with delivery.
review.cervix-dilation: 5cm/hour in nulliparous women 10cm/hour in multiparous women
review.basal-cell-carcinoma: Most common type of skin cancer. Most are located on face and neck. Sometimes donut shaped, pearly papule with a waxy border. Most are localized and do not metastasize.
review.actinic-keratosis: Small papule with rough, dry, scaly skin.
review.squamous-cell-carcinoma: Firm nodular lesion covered by crust.
review.ciprofloxacin: Class of drugs known as fluoroquinolones. Milk, yougurt and ceffeine interferes with medication absorption, avoid taking together with the medicine. Could be consumed in between doses though. Calcium could alter absorption and should not be taken within 6 hours of the medication. Could be taken with or without meals. Increase in fluid intake is required to prevent crystalluria and renal calculi, cipro increases the risk for both. May cause increased sensitivity to sun.
review.pregnancy-low-back-pain: Intermittent low back pain could indicate overly distended uterus and could be a sign of oncoming labor. Especially if there are multiple fetuses.
review.false-labor: Contractions are irregular and don't get closer together. Don't start from the back and radiate through the abdomen, unlike in true labor. Usually the pain is only felt in the front. Contractions stop with relaxation.
review.chemical-stress-test: Medications most commonly used: Dipyridamole thallium 201 Adenosine Dobutamine IV medications given to clients to simulate a stress test on the heart when client is unable to do physical activity. A sonogram is performed to detect any abnormalities.
review.mixing-insulin: Done to avoid giving the patient multiple injections if they require both short term and extended action insulin injections. Most commonly mixed insulins are regular and NPH (Neutral Protamine Hagedorn) Never mix insulin Glargine (Lantus) with any other insulin. Administer the injection within 5-10 min after drawing it up because regular insulin binds to NPH and decreases the action (of regular insulin). Why does the order matter: NPH insulin should not be introduced into regular insulin vial because of the binding effect.
review.tendonitis: Treatment is applying ice, resting and analgesics.
review.end-of-life: Clients often times refuse fluids in last days, effects of dehydration take a toll on the mind. Clients could experience restlessness, agitation and hallucinations.
review.colorectal-cancer: Risk factors: obesity, smoking, alcohol, physical inactivity and diet. Other risk factors: Age (45+), Race(African-American and Eastern Jewish), Type II Diabetes
review.nutrition-fat: Saturated and trans: solid at room temperature, found in animal tallow Places: butter, pork, chicken and beef fat, cakes, nuts, chips, tropical plant oils (coconut, palm etc.), margerine
review.adult-diaper: To ensure proper fit front absorbent matt should come to the naval Change diaper after 20 ounces of absorbency is reached or after 2 wettings, usually 2-3 times per day. Avoid wearing a large diaper to avoid frequent changes. Use a barrier cream such as zinc oxide after each diaper change.
review.urge-incontinence: Also called overactive bladder Sudden urge to urinate with no control Often due to damage to the nerves
review.stress-urinary-incontinence: Release of urine when bladder is physically stressed (pressed) from physical activity, jumping, laughing, sneezing etc.
review.neurogenic-shock: Loss of sympathetic tone. Most common cuase is damage to the spinal column above T6 Symptoms are dry, warm skin, low bp and maybe brady cardia.
review.games-by-age: Toddler (1.5-3) - picture books, pounding board, regular household items, many opportunities for exploration, 4 - 12 piece wood puzzles, blocks, cars, crayons, large paintbrush, dolls, balls, push-pull toys, rocking horses. Pre-Schooler (3-5) - dress up clothes, tricycle, skates.
review.hypokalemia: Symptoms: Muscle weakness, especially in the legs. Parasthesia in the hands.
review.why-questions: Don't ask why questions - they are confrontational.
review.Guillain-Barre-Syndrome: Ascending paralysis that starts with tingling in feet and could paralyze the body, including breathing and swallowing. Could be triggered by a viral or a bacterial infection. Autoimmune condition which affects the myelination of the nerves. Treatments could include plasma exchange and immunoglobulin therapy. Has no effect on cognitive function. Recovery happens in 90% of cases but usually takes several months to a few years.
review.central-venous-access: Femoral site has a higher chance for infection, femoral site is only used if subclavian site is unavailble.
review.tuberculosis: Endemic in certain parts of asia, people from Asian countries should be screened for it.
review.fundus-decension: Rate of 1cm per day, after 10 days should be below the pubic bone. Subinvolution could cause hemorrhage.
review.lochia: Rubra - 1 to 4 days after birth, small blood clots not larger than plum are normal Serosa - pink to brown discharge, 4-10 days after delivery Alba - yellow, whitish discharge from 10 - 14 days.
review.postpartum-assessment: Massage boggy uterus. Monitor for thrombophlebitis in legs, to prevent - ambulate.
review.brain-lobes: parietal - sensation and orientation in space temporal - audio processing occipital - visual frontal - higher order fuctions, personality, speech, emotions.
review.dementia-bathing: Sing or talk continuously to help the client relax. Expose only one area at a time to keep warm and provide privacy Bathe slowly and explain every step.
review.cardio-pulmonary-resucitation: Assess for responsiveness - make sure the patient is not sleeping or easily roused Activate emergency response- shout to someone to call 911 Check the pulse as you scan for signs of life - if yes, check breathing if no, go to next step Begin chest compressions After 30 compressions - open the airway and give two breaths Resume compressions and breaths at ratio of 30:2
review.prenatal-diagnostics: Glucose tolerance test HIV test Hep B test Blood typing STI test
review.maternal-serum-alpha-fetoprotein: Blood test given to the mother at 15-20 weeks (second trimester) Assesses for neural tube defects (such as spina bifida or ananecephaly) and other chromosomal abnormalities.
review.bone-marrow-biopsy: Using bones such as iliac crest or sternum Could result in heavy bleeding due to deep penetration of tissue.
review.anxiety: Anxiety is a normal response to stress. Management of anxiety is geared with learning to cope with existing experiences, not seeking out new ones to "conquer" anxiety. Calling the therapis every time there is some anxiety is not recommended since the patient might become too reliant on them.
review.phenozopyridine: Causes urine to become organge or red, which is normal. If the kidneys cannot excrete it fast enough then the skin could become dislored too, in which case the med should be stopped immediately.
review.post-partum: It's normal to urinate up to 3000ml per day for 2-3 days post, as fluid accumulated during pregnancy is leaving the body.
review.Naegeles-rule: Determine first day of last menstrual period Subtract 3 calendar months from that time Add 7 days
review.fundal-height: Increases by 1cm/week starting at 12-14 weeks and lasts until 36 weeks, then it varies. Rises just above the pubis symphysis at about 12-14 weeks.
review.colostomy: Rinsing or reusing the ostomy pouch is not recommended. Do not reduce fluid intake to make the stool harder.
review.pacemakers: Hearing aid may affect placement of the transmitter, as it shouldn't come within 6 inches of it. Avoid placing devices that are battery operated or magnetic close to the transmitter. Do not stay long near anti-theft devlices (like metal detecotrs) walk through them at a normal pace. Avoid welding equipment, large generators, radar towers, and MRIs. Usually placed in upper left chest or under left clavicle. Electrical equipment that is grounded and well mantained is ok. Common house appliances like microwaves, remotes, electric blankets will not affect the pacemaker.
review.Dupuytrens-contracture: Thickening of skin near the base of the palm which causes fingers to contract towards the wrist or deflect. Most often affects ring and pinky fingers. Treatment includes surgery, using a needle to break the tissue and enzyme injections to soften the tissue. Most commonly associated with middle age (50+) men of Scandinavian or Celtic descnet and is assaociated with diabetes, gout, arthritis and alcoholism.
review.Duchenne-muscular-dystrophy: Genetic disorder characterizide by progressive muscle degeneration. Typically found in boys. Starts around ages 2-3, affects the legs first, affects the heart and breathing muscles later. Life expectancy is around 16 to early 20s.
review.cataracts: After surgery: avoid increasing IOP, avoid sleeping on affected side, wear an eye patch at night and glasses durinig the day, avoid getting water in the eye, avoid prolonged reading or eye strain.
review.packed-red-blood-cells: Administered with 18G catheter. Should be administered in less than 4 hours to prevent bacterial contamination.
review.loop-diuretic: Examples: furosemide, bumetanide, torsemide They are potassium wasting.
review.interpersonal-behviour: Do not ask why questions, they are confrontational even before the facts are known. Do not involve emotional aspects into your questions as they are also confrontational.
review.hepatitis-a: Transmission: Fecal-oral route. Not transmitted through the blood. Take care traveling to high to medium level affected couintries such as Africa, South America, and Asia.
review.blood-pressure: Optimal position for measuring BP is sitting upright. Laying down may incrase the reading by as much as 8 mmHg
review.dehydration: Symptoms: dry skin, tachycardia, cold extremities.
review.lithium: Early toxicity includes symptoms of nausea, vomiting and diarrhea Severe toxicity is characterized by ataxia, confusion and seizures.
review.carbohydrates: Increase the production of CO2, avoid in respiratory compromised clients.
review.dose-adjustment: Must be verified by two nurses for important medications like insulin and heparin.
review.theraputic-communication: If client is experiencing a concern about an issue, first normalize the experience, then explain what to do about the actual issue.
review.seizure: Loosen clothing, place pillow under the head, place clinet on side with head flexed forward and down so that saliva could drain and tongue can roll forward.
review.colorectal-cancer: Screening: colonoscopy every 10 years after age of 45, if barium enema is selected for screen should be done every 5 years, if fecalt occult blood is selected as screening method it should be done every year.
review.Hegars-sign: Softening of the cervix, indicative of pregnancy, palpated on a bimanual exam. Sign is present from 4th week until the 12th week of pregnancy.
review.quickening: First movement of the fetus, usually occurs in 18th or 20th week of pregnancy.
review.positive-sign-of-pregnancy: Auscultation of fetal heart beat, which can usually be first auscultated at 12 weeks.
review.deep-vein-thrombosis: Massage is contraindicated in clients that are at an increased risk for DVT, due to the possibility of dislodging the thrombus. Sequantial pressure device should instead be used.
review.African-American: Higher risk of colorectal cancer and lung cancer.
review.unlicensed-assistive-personal: Can collect stool samples and measure and record blood-pressure.
review.malpractice: A type of negligence where a there is a failure to act as a competent person would normally act in that situation. Does not have to be intentional. Requres four elements to be proven, the four Ds : Damages - Injury is present, Direct cause - cuasation is present, Duty - had the duty to care for the person at the moment, dereliction - breach of duty Examples: improper use of equipment, failure to act in emergency, inapropriate medication administration.
review.cluster-headaches: One of the most painful types of headaches. Occur in one side of the head. Acute treatment is to provide 100% oxygen at 6-8L/min for 10 min. May be repeated after a 5 min rest. Oxygen causes vasoconstriction and increases the synthesis of serotonin in the central-nervous-system. Sumatriptan could be given.
review.colostomy: Assess the new stoma every 4 hours post surgery.
review.laryngectomy-suctioning: Only performed as necessary to prevent complications. Suction laryngectomy tube first, then mouth to prevent contamination.
review.diabetic-ketoacidosis: Plyuria - body is trying to get rid of excess sugar Hypotension - as a result of dehydration
review.chemotherapy-precautions: Medications remain in the client's body for 3-7 days. Clinets who recieved chemo in the last 48 hours shold be under chemotherapy precautions. Wear two pairs of chemotherapy approved gloves, one on top of the other. When contacting the client, linens, or fluids also wear a special gown. Hands must always be washed with soap after removal of ppe. Flush toilet twice after disposing of fluids.
review.standard-precautions: Hand hygine Use of proper PPE for the procedure. Sharps safety.
review.droplet-precautions: Mask on patient when transporting. Single room or room with similarly infected. Could leave door open (droplets fall on floor after expiration).
review.Addisons-disease: Sodium wasting, potassium saving - lack of aldosterone and cortisol results in hyperkalemia. Dehydration and hypovolemia could trigger Addisonian-crisis. Simple stress could execerbate symptoms (due to lack of cortisol, which helps the body respond to stress). Results in a destruction of the adrenal cortex. Lack of cortisol increases insulin production and reduces glucose production causing hypoglycemia. Lack of cortisol decreases sensitivity to catecholamines, causing hypotension. Lack of immune response causes infections.
review.aldosterone: Functions to retain sodium and excrete potassium.
review.cortisol: Increases release of glucose and decreases insulin production. Increases sensistivity to chatecholamines.
review.antisocial-personality-disorder: Provide safety for other clients. Establish and enforce limits. Avoid making deals. Anger can be used to manipulate.
review.toilet-training:
Four signs to indicate readiness: waking up dry from a nap being aware of the urge communicating the need to go being dry for at least 2 hours during the day
Bowel control is established before urinary control.
Bed wetting is normal in girls until 4yo and in boys until 5yo. Alert the doctor if child doesn't achieve control by 6yo. Night time bladder control occurs a few months after day time control is achieved.
Provide a potty chair rather than having to start with a toilet and allows the child to place feet on floor.
Avoid long training sessions, limit to 5-10 min in the bathroom.
review.nasal-canula: Maximum flow rate is at 6L/min FiO2 22-44%
review.simple-face-mask: Minimal flow rate 6L/min (any lower and the client will rebreath) maximum 10L/min FiO2 - 40-60% For oxygen conterations exceeding 60% a mask with a reserviour must be used.
review.partial-rebreather-mask: Has a two way valve between the bag and the mask, mask has no openings into the atmosphere. Flow rate 6-8L/min FiO2 60-80%
review.non-rebreather-mask: Has a one way valve between mask and bag and a one way valve to the atmosphere. Flow rate 10-15L/min FiO2 - 60-90%
review.foreign-body-airway-obstruction: Never perform a blind finger sweep of mouth - can push the object further down. In infants less than 1 years: Alternate 5 back blows and 5 chest compressions until object clears or infant becomes unresponsive. Children 1 - 8: Heimlich manuver until unresponsive. If none of these work: begin direct rigid bronchoscopy. If the object can not be removed - if it is above vocal chords - perform a cricothyrotomy, if below then et tube.
review.infectious-mononucleosis: Kissing disease. Caused by Epstein-Barr virus. Passed from person to person through saliva, but no extra precautions beyond standard need to be used.
review.herpes-zoster: Aka. Shingles. Requires airborne and contact precautions. Observed until the lesions are dry and crusted.
review.hemodialysis: Hold antihypertensives - could lower BP too much Hold antibiotics - will be removed with dialysate Do not hold insulin Do not hold pain medication
review.cushing-disease: High protein diet to minimize muscle wasting. Low carb diet to not gain weight. Low calorie diet. High potassium diet because of high potassium excretion by the kidney.
review.bladder-cancer: Associated strongly with smoking. Not associated with alcohol consumption.
review.enteral-nutrition: Air in line could cause flatulance. Incorrect temperature can cause diarrhea. Too much residual indiciates slow digestion and could cause nausea.
review.patient-education: Do not ask "Do you understand or do you have any questions"? - Patient maybe be uncomfortable in answering yes to those. Say "tell me about" or "What questions do you have?" Do not ask simple yes or no questions.
review.broken-arm: Evaluate a neurovascular status of the extremity, apply ice, then splint and elevate.
review.meconium-in-utero: Suction mouth and nose with a bulb syringe. No need to suction the trachea.
review.reynold-syndrome: Blood vessel constriction with stress or cold, usually effects the nose and fingers. Treatment isn't needed.
review.theophylline: Used as tablets to control asthma, by relaxing airway muscles. Theraputic range is 10-20 mcg/ml of blood. Toxicity is over 20 mcg/ml
review.lithium: Theraputic range for initial management is 1 - 1.5 mEq. Management doses are lower at 0.8 - 1.2 mEq/L .
review.wet-to-dry-dressing: Usually requires pain medication. Used as a method of debridment, lower layers dry and pull of eschar. Remove old tape - pull parallel to skin, towards the dressing.
review.feeding-tube: During insertion if patient is coughing the tube is in the trachea, remove the tube and let patinet rest before attempting reinsertion.
review.peritoneal-dialysis: Abdominal pain is common during the first few exchanges. It's due to peritonieal irritation. It usually subsides in 1 to 2 weeks of treatment.
review.vegan-diet: Lack vitamin D, Calcium from dairy and Vit B12, and Iron from meats. Have vitamin B1 and A which are found in vegies.
review.pregnancy-nausea: Associated with an increase in human chorionic gonadotropin hormone. Could start as early as 4 weeks. Should diminish by 14th week of pregnancy. Eating a dry carbohydrate immediately upon arising. Eating more protein with an evening meal might help, like a bedtimes snack of penut butter or cheese. Eat salty or sour food (potato chips or lemonade) during periods of nausea. Consume ginger foods or teas. Don't brush teeth immediately after eating. Do not delay meals, excessive hunger could cause nausea. Avoid consuming fluids early in the day, during nausea or after meals.
review.asthma: For kids, give the inhaler and spacer to nurse not teacher and don't have them carry it with them.
review.sudden-vaginal-bleeding: Ask when the first day of last period was to determine if it's a possible spontaneous abortion. Ask when bleeding started to estimate blood loss.
review.statin: Common side effects: rash, headach, GI disturbances. Important side effect: muscle pain or tenderness - could indicate myositis or muscle inflammation which could lead to rhabdomyolysis, which could lead to kidney failure.
review.paracentesis: Removal of fluid from the abdomen. Positioned in a supine position with head of bed slightly elevated.
review.pheochromocytoma: Benign tumor of the adrenal glands, causes hypertension.
review.pre-filled-syringe: Do not expell the air bubble. It prevents leakage by pushing the medicine into the tissue.
review.social-readjustment-rating-scale:
Rates life events on a scale of most stressful to least, some common ones:
Death of a spouce (100) Divorce (76) Jail Term (63) Death of close family member (63) Fired at work (47) Foreclosure (30) Children leaving home (29) Trouble with boss (23) Minor violation of the law (11)
review.beginning-of-labor: Bloody show - vaginal discharge with a little blood indicates the end of pregnancy and begnning of labor. Contractions are felt in lower black Fetal movement decreases
review.personal-protective-equipment: Remove the PPE just prior (not after) existing the containemnt room.
review.lower-back-pain: Best position for pain relief is in bed with head levated 45 degrees and knees moderately flexed - flexingin the knees relieves pressure on the sciatic nerve. Knees should be higher than hips.
review.informed-concent: Should be obtained from next of kin or spouce if the client is not mentally competent.
review.heel-pressure-injury: Place a roll under calf, not under achilles tendon as that will cause injury. Wear socks when in bed to reduce injury from friction. Do not massage the area as that will increase tissue breakdown.
review.crutches: Should be kept 8-10 inches to the side. Elbows flexed at 20-30 degrees.
review.incident-report: Do not document the fact that incident report was filed in the client's health record.
review.post-anesthesia: Fine crackles are an expected finding.
review.calcium: Protein bound, so with low protein calcium could be low as well.
review.wound-healing: Monitor albumin (norm: 3.5-5) and total protein. Adequate intake of protein, vitamin C and zinc. Foods such as meat (protein and zinc), legumes (zinc), nuts (zinc), dairy (zinc)
review.oral-steroids: Are ulcerogenic and should be adminsted with meals.
review.pediatric-vitals: See pediatric_vitals.png chart in the downloads folder.
review.neonate-ointment: Usually tetracycline or erythromycin. Prevents opthalmia neonatorum, caused by gonorrheal or chalmydial infection.
review.atrial-fibrillation: Could be treateed with amiodarone and digoxin, watch for toxicities such as blurred vision and halos.
review.contrast: If given to renal patient, time with dialysis to immediately remove the contrast from the blood. Oral contrast could contain a laxative to prevent constipation and promote explusion, so diarrhea is normal after the procedure.
review.Addisons-disease: Hypoglycemia - due to lack of cortisol. Hyperpigmentation - caused by excess ACTH Weight loss - due to continued loss of water Low blood pressure
review.common-supplements: Feverfew - used to prevent migranes, interacts with platelet aggregation and so should not be used with aspirin and warfarin/heparin. Echinacea - used to decrease inflammation and manage infections, suppresses immune system should not be combined with HIV, TB or cancer medications. Valerian - interacts with depressent meds. St.John's wort - treats depression, interacts with antidepressants and could cause excess serotonin and serotonin syndrome.
review.pregnancy-adaptations: Blood pressure decreases as the pregnancy goes on in response to vasodialating effect of progesterone.
review.pediatric-pain-management: Neonate - Infant (0-1): sucrose on the pacifier, swaddling and swaying. Toddler - Preschooler (1-5): toys books, singing. School age - video games, tv
review.Self-Determination-Act: Requires providers to provide information to clients about the patient rights, so they can make a decision for themselves.
review.omnibus-budget-reconciliation-act: Provides clients with rights to be free from physical or chimical restraints as a method of discipline or convience.
review.tarasoff-ruling: Required reporting of planned self harm or harm to others.
review.insulin: Lispro - very fast acting - onset 15-30 min, peak on 30 min to 90 min, duration 3-5 hours. Regular - onset 30-60min, 1-5 hours peak, duration 6-10 hours. Neutral Protamine Hagedorn - intermediate acting, peak action of 4-12 hours, duration of 16 hours. Glargine - onset 3-4 hours, no peak, 24 hours duration.
review.kidney-stones: Calcium oxalate - comes from green leafy vegetalbes, like rhubarb, also cola, tea, chocolate and high doses of vitamin C. Struvite stones - associated with urinary tract infectionotin, need to acidify the urine by increaseing egg consumption, as well as consumption of fish and cranberries. Uric acid stones - cut down on foods high in purines such as red meat, organ meats, beer and alcohol, sardines, shellfish. Cystine stones - caused by a rare disorder which elevates cystine in the blood, urine needs to be more alkaline so consumption of milk, nuts and vegetables needs to be increased.
review.epoetin-alpha: Hemoglobin should not increase rapidly or above 12 g/dL or the risk of thromboembolytic events increases. Once hemoglobin approaches 11 g/dL or if hemoglobin rises by more than 1g/dL in a 2 week period, dosage should be decreased by 25%. This threshold is lower for clients with chronic-kidney-disease.
review.hispanic-culture: Silence is a sign of disagreement. Direct eye contact is avoided with authority figures. Prefer social interactions before being asked personal questions.
review.anaphylectic-reaction: Runny nose and sneezing is indicative of an atopic reacon but not anaphylaxis. Diffuse rash is not indicative of anaphylaxis and does not happen immediately.
review.heart-failure: Ejection fraction 55% - 70% Normal level 40-50% - may be asymptomatic 35-39% - mild heart failure, may have dyspnea. less than 35% - moderate to severe.
review.Alzheimers: Should only cook with supervision. Don't argue. Place limits on wrong behaviours. Focus on feelings rather than words, for example "you seem worried"
review.burns:
Monitor hemodynamics frequently and administer fluids to prevent hypovolemic shock. Diet high in calories, vitamin C, Zinc and protein. Daily weights, 2% weight loss from pre burn weight is a mild caloric deficit, over 10% requires modification of intake. Positing and range of motion exercies.
Totol body surface area: 18% back / 18% front 9% each arm (4.5% back and front) 18% each leg (9% back and front) 9% head (4.5% back and front) 1% perenium
review.bulemia: Set eating habits and make a contract. Monitor for one hour to prevent purging.
review.antihypertensives: Should be taken in the morning as the meds are most effective when the client is active.
review.restraints: Never attach them to side rails, must be attached to a stable portion of the bed frame.
review.tracheostomy: Track cleaning and care should be done every 8 hours. During first few days secretions tend to be thick. Keep a spare of same size or larger at bedside. Wait 24 hours to chage ties to prevent irritating the trachea. Changing ties or moving the trach tube could irritate the trachea and cause coughing. Suction when there is a moist cough or hypoxia. In case of dislodgement, notify physician and respiratory therapist, raise the clients head of bed
review.croup: Barking cough caused by a virus. Treatment is dexamethasone.
review.performace-improvement-nurse: Reports are not meant to get other nurses in trouble or for disciplinary actions.
review.peritonitis: Adbominal pain and rebound tenderness. Vomiting, diarrhea and hyperactive bowel sounds.
review.peritoneal-dialysis: First indication is a cloudy return dialysate solution. Requires sterile technique.
review.wet-to-dry-dressing:
Wash hands and prepare your sterile field before removing the old dressing.
Purpose is to absorb drainage and trap debris as the dressing dries. Dressing must be damp not entirely wet. Number of layer depened on the depth of the wound. All wound surfaces have to be in contact with the wet gauze, including dead spaces and tunnels. Number of pieces of gauze should be counted and recorded to make sure they're all removed later. Damp gauze should not touch the skin around the wound.
review.negative-pressure-wound-therapy: If pump stops working or falls off, patient should inform the nurse immediately. NPWT dressing should not be kept on without the pump for more than 2 hours otherwise infection is possible. Dressing should be removed completely and a wet to dry dressing should be applied until the pump is fixed.
review.implanted-port: Could swim and shower with it. Don't need daily flushing.
review.sodium: Regular intake should be less than 3,000 mg per day. Restricted intake should be less than 2,000 mg per day. Minimum intake is 500 mg per day.
review.licensed-nurse-practitioner: Collecting specimens such as blood, urine and sputum. Changing wound dressings.
review.respiratory-rate: Newborn: 25-55 bpm Infant (6-12mo): 24-30 bpm Young child (1-5yo): 20-30 bpm Child(6+): 12-20 bpm
review.pulmonary-embolism: Typically occurs 12-72 hours after injury to a long bone. Petechia on the chest and mucus membranes.
review.deep-vein-thrombosis: Throbbin pain in the extremity. Swelling, redness, warmth and pain in the area.
review.electro-cardio-gram: Five large squares is 1 second. Thirty large squares represent 6 seconds.
review.surgical-dress-code: Must wear cap at all times. Hair should be clipped, not shaved. Shirt shold be tucked in pants to avoid skin shedding and prevent contact with sterile fields. Nails should be short and unpolished.
review.incident-report: Should be completed even in cases of near misses, where for example a wrong medication was almost given (even though it wasn't)
review.low-fat-diet: Canadian bacon - considerably leaner than regular bacon and could be incorporated into healthy meals.
review.diabetes: Rist factors: Race - African American, Hispanic, Native American and Asian Age - greater than 45 Pregnancy - newborn weighing more than 9 lbs
review.breastfeeding: Newborn should feed every 1.5-3 hours, if not feeding after 3 hours, must awaken the baby and feed. Breast goes from firm to soft after feeding. Infant should be heard swollowing.
review.diapers: New borns should have 6-8 wet diapers daily (at least every 4 hours).
review.developmental-milestones: 1st - walks without help 2nd - builds a tower of 3-4 blocks 3rd - Uses 2-3 word phrases 4th - Jumps with both feet
review.water-breaking:
Anytime there is a change in labor status the first step is to assess the fetal well being by ausultating the heart rate: Below 110 - late sign of fetal hypoxia maybe due to a prolapsed cord (when the cord exists the cervix before the baby) Above 160 - early sign of fetal hypoxia.
Check for a prolapsed cord. Fluid should be straw colored - green or brown fluid should be reported. pH of fluid is used to distinguish it from urine - normal pH should be alkaline or 7 and above.
review.prolapsed-cord: Push on the presenting cord to relieve pressure. Place the client in Trendelenburg position or knee-chest position.
review.autograft: Usually immobilized and elevated for 3-7 days.
review.dopamine: Used as a vasopressor to increase cardiac output.
review.cast: Cannot perform range of motion exercises on an extremity with a cast. Muscle "setting" of the limb in the cast is the best exercies - it's isometric - involves ontracting and releaseing the muscles. If a leg is immobilized, quadricept setting must be used to maintain muscle strenght. Maintain contraction for a few seconds for 10 sets. Must be done every hour to maintain strenght.
review.compartment-syndrome: Pain, Pulse, Parasthesia, Paralysis, Pale, Poikilothermia (cool extremity)
review.chest-tube: Measured hourly during the first 24 hours after surgery. If more than 200 mL of drainage occurs during the first hour and more than 100 mL per hour in the hours after, surgeon should be notified. Wall suction must be at least -80mmHg to maintain -20cm H2O in the suction chamber. Avoid dependent loops If chest tube becomes dislodges from the chest, place a dry gauze over the incision and tape on 3 side, making sure to leave one side untaped as to allow relief of pressure. If the connection becomes dislodged at the chamber level place the end of the tube into 1-2 in of water.
review.hip-replacement: Leg must be abducted in order to maintain proper limb orientation. Use an abductor pillow that's triangle shaped.
review.purine: Shellfish and mussels are high in purine.
review.gout: Caused by uric acid crystals in joints, which is convereted from purine. Increase fluid intake to over 2L / day Avoid alcohol and beer as well as high fructose corn syrup. Avoid organ meats and shellfish.
review.common-diseases: mononucleosis - standard precautions (Epstein-Barr virus) - fatigue, fever and swollen lymph nodes. Spread by saliva. hepatitis A - spread by the stool of the person. Toxic shock syndrome - cannot be transmitted to others. Rhinovirus - common cold, droplet transmission.
review.hepatitis: A - spread through feces B - all fluids, except feces urine and vomit C - mostly blood, usually not through sex or feces or urine or vomit. D - all fluids, except for feces, urine and vomit.
review.withdrawl: Cannabis withdrawl - insomnia, lack of appetite and hyperactivity Narcotics - watery eyes, cramps and mild tremors. Alcohol - hyperalterness, easily startled, anorexia, anxeity, tremors, insomnia, seizures up to 72 hours after last drink, tacticle disturbances (itching, pins and needles etc)
review.alcohol-withdrawal:
Use Clinical Institute Withdrawl Assessment for Alcohol, Revise (CIWA-Ar) scale. To check for tremors by extending arms and spreading fingers. Even if not visible touch fingertip to feel for vibration. Scale checks for N/V: 0-7 points Tremor: 0-7 points Sweating: 0-7 points Agitation: 0-7 points Tactile distrubances: 0-7 Auditory disturbance: 0-7 Visual distrubances: 0-7 Headache: 0-7 Orientation: 0-4
Total: 0-67 less than 9: very mild 10-15: mild 16-20: modest 21-67: severe withdrawl
Check cerum electrolytes and coagulation along with CBC Other symptoms are tachycardia and hypertension
review.risperidone: Can cause photosensitivity and impaired temperature regulation. Can cause orthostatic hypotension. Dry mouth
review.ectopic-pregnancy: Unilateral, dull abdominal pain. Could present as reffered should pain due to the blood irritating the subdiaphragmatic phrenic nerve. Could be fatal to the woman due to potential rupture of the fellopian tube and hemorrhage.
review.spontaneous-abortion: Frank, red bleeding and moderate cramps.
review.normal-effects-of-pregnancy: Whitish vaginal secretions during the first trimester of pregnancy are normal. Breast tenderness and amenorrhea.
review.hyperemesis-gravidum: Excessive nausea and vomiting. Could be a sign of hydatidiform mole, due to high levels of hCg
review.infant-apnea: Sessation of breathing for more than 20 seconds or if shorter but accompanied by bradycardia, cyanosis, or marked hypotonia. Sessation of breathing for periods of less than 20 seconds with no complicating factors is considered normal in neonates, it's called periodic breathing. Diagnosis is much more common in preterm infants, and rare in full term. When it's diagnosed in full term infants, it's usually indicative of an underlying issue.
review.neonate: Report fever greater than 101F (38.3C) More than one episode of projectile vomiting should be reported as it's not normal.
review.pneumonia: Risk factors are underlying lung conditions, shallow breathing due to broken ribs (lack of lung expansion causes pneumonia), anything that decreases lung expansion like bed rest.
review.therapy: Flooding - rapid desensitization where the person is suddenly introduced to the feared subject to learn how to handle it. Cognitive Behaviour Therapy - attempts to explain how the persons interpretations and perceptions influences behaviour. Psychodynamic therapy - examining past events to see how they reflect the future or current status of the client. Psychoterapy - based on Freud that sexual energy drives developement. Use of free association, dream analysis - disocovers the source of repressed thoughts to resolve current conflicts. Erikson - focuses on acheiving healthy psychosocial developmental milestones as defined by Erikson. Maslow - focus on the whole person, focus on the current situation and solve the problems one level at a time.
review.transfusion-related-lung-injury: Rare but serious syndrome characterized by acute respiratory difficulty following a transfusion (either immediately during or up to 6 hours after). Rapid onset of dyspnea and drop of SpO2 less than 90% High morbidity with majority of the patients requiring ventialtor support. Lung injury is usually transient and resolve within 48-96 hours with supportive care. Could occur due to the client's antibodies activating donor's leukocytes or donor's antibodies activating client lekocytes. Leads to sequestration of hyperactive neutrophils along the lung epithelium which leads to pulmonary edema. To reduce the risk give, leukocyte reduced blood. In case of an event, obtain HLA (human leukocyte antibody) blood test, chest x-ray, oxygen, corticosteroids. Have intubation equipment ready.
review.blood-transfusion: Reduced leukocyte blood products are given to those that expereinced a transfusion reaction before. Diphenhydramine, acetaminophen and hydrocortisone is given to clients with high risk of rejection.
review.apnea-monitor: White and Black lead - upper right chest and upper left chest Green lead - on abdomen, not over bony area.
review.infant-sleep: Do not use soft mattresses due to increased risk of SIDS, use a firm mattress. Do not use bumper guards for same reason. Do not rock the baby to sleep as that introduces dependence. Instead place them in the crib and let them fall asleep. Sleep pattern should be developed by 4 months of age. Sleep should last 9-11 hours. Total daily sleep should be about 15 hours.
review.preoperative-medication-hold: Hold all medications that effect hydration and bleeding times. Hold diuretics as they increase the risk for hypovolemia and hypokalemia. Hold anticoagulats to reduce the risk of severe bleeding.
review.bulimia-nervosa: A vicious cycle where the client diets and then binge eats a large quantity of food, then attempts to rid of the food by endusing vomiting. Focus is to interrup the cycle. Altering dysfunctional thoughts. Exploring self-concept. Set limits on eating - like only at a table or with others. Weight is usually in the normal range. Usually aware of the problem and are ashamed. May brush teeth frequently.
review.anorexia-nervosa: Restricting eating to maintain a percieved proper weight. Usually underweight. Intense fear of gaining weight. Multiple measurements of weight daily. Don't allow food to touch teeth. Counting bites Usually refuse to acknowledge the problem.
review.radiation-therapy: Consipation is a common side effecet if abdomen is irradiated. Alopecia is expected if head is irradiated. Fatige is a common and expected side effect. Rash could occur and must be treated. Could result in difficulty in swollowing due to inflammation and thus require further intervention.
review.vomiting: In complicated clients, elevate head of bed, suction the mouth, check lung sounds, and notify provider.
review.lumbar-puncture: Hydrate well before the procedure. Instruct to void. Either sit on the side of the bed while leaning forward or tuck knees to chest and lay on side. Local anesthetic is injected. Spinal needle is inserted into subarachnoid space. Pressure in the space is measured then CSF is withdrawn. Client may feel some pressure and brief sharp pain with tingling down one or both legs.
review.suctioning: Hyperoxygenate for 30 seconds, suction for 5-10 seconds at a time.
review.biot-respirations: Seen in patients with brain damage. A cycle of rapid respirations followed by short period of apnea.
review.cheyne-stokes-respirations: Seen in patients with heart problems. A cycle that alternates between fast deep breaths with slow shallow respirations.
review.wheezing: Mostly during expiration but could also occur during inspiration.
review.metoclopromide: Stimulates the motility of upper GI tract and decreases nausea.
review.cardio-pulmonary-resucitation: First do chest compressions then open the airway after 30 compressions.
review.diabetes-insipidus: Could be caused by deteriorating head trauma from the pressure on the pituitary gland.
review.cocaine: Symptoms include insomnia, facial pain due to inhalation, and rhinnorhea due to nasal administration.
review.evidence-collection: ] Evidence is placed in a paper bag, not plastic, in order to avoid moisture buildup which could cause bacteria to detriorate DNA or other evidence. Bullets should be wrapped in gauze and placed in a cup or envelope. Save any grass or dirt. Swabs of any secretions should be air dried prior to storage.
review.varicella: If an immonocompromised client is exposed the priority is to administer varicella immunoglobulin, which can prevent the development of infection. Requires contact and droplet precautions.
review.rupture-of-membranes: Avoid ambulating after the membranes have ruptured as it risks a prolapsed umbilical cord. Only allow ambulations prior to ROM.
review.pregnancy-position: Preferred is side lying. Could also be supine with a pillow under hips as this prevents the uterus from compressing aorta and vena cava.
review.pressure-injury: Have head of bed elevated at less than 30 degrees to prevent shear.
review.informed-concent: If client has questions or is not sure they understood the information provided by the health care provider during the signing, a nurse could clarify any questions. No need to contact the provider unless the patient has questions which are beyond the scope of nurses knowledge.
review.normal-saline: Contains 154 mEq sodium and 154 mEq of chloride. Increases fluid volume, adminisgted to treat volume deficit.
review.lactaded-ringer: Contains sodium chloride, sodium lactate, potassium, calcium. Does not provide potassium replacement. Contains electrolyte content that closely resembles blood plasma and serum. Used to pelace GI tract fluid losses, fistula drainage, and fluid losses due to burns and trauma. Given to clients with acute blood loss and third space fluid shifts. Must be used carefully in renal patients due to potassium. Must also be used cautiosly in patients with liver disease because liver converts lactate to bicarbonate. Used as an alkalinizing agent to raise the body's pH.
review.dextrose-in-water: Initially isotonic, but dextrose is quickly metabolized by the body leaving no osmotic particles and thus becomes hypotonic and infuses into cells. Provides 170 calories per liter. Used to treat hypernatremia. Not used during fluid resuscitation.
review.fluid-replacement: Average client with healthy kidneys requires 2,600ml of fluid to replace fluid loss, 30 to 150 mEq sodium/day. 40-60 potassium per day.
review.hypotonic-solution: Solution that has less than 250 mEq/L of electrolytes. Causes fluid to move into the cells.
review.hypertonic-solution: Causes fluid to move into the blood. Called fluid expanders. A solution is considered hypertonic if it has a total electrolyte concentration exceeding 375 mEq/L. Example are any isotonic fluid plus 5% dextrose, like D5-0.45-NS
review.cyanocobalamin: Metformin, proton pump inhibitors, and histamine receptor antagonists (h2 antagonists like famotidine) interfere with absoprtion.
review.breastfeeding: Immunoglobulin A is passed in breastmilk. This provides passive immunity for the first 3 months of life.
review.breast-exam: Done 1 week after the onset of menses when hormonal influences on the breasts are low.
review.walker: To sit down take small steps back towards the chair until the chair hits the back of the legs. Client should not lean over the handles and instead stand tall.
review.nits: Keep permethrin cream on for 10 minutes before washing off. Permetherin may irritate scalp and skin. Linens should be washed in hot water and then dried in dryer. Not necessary to use bleach.
review.prescription: Should not use decimal points when there is a trailing zero as it could be misinterpreted. If unable to read the handwriting have to call the doctor, not ask another nurse.
review.abdominal-binder: Used after surgery to like c-section, laparotomy or hernia repair to compress the section of the abdomen. Worn as a band around the abdomen. Could be applied by a UAP but nurse needs to assess the area first.
review.nasogastric-tube: Measure from the tip of the nose to the ear lobe then to the xiphoid process.
review.evacuation-of-children: Place identification bracelets on each to easily track and ID them.
review.rh-immune-globulin: Works for 12 weeks Should be administered between 26-28 weeks of pregnancy (since it works for 12 weeks) and then within 72 hours of delivery to reduce the risk of rejection on following pregancies.
review.asthma-attack: If a child is wheezing after excersize and has an albuterol inhaler, first determine the peak expiratory flow rate (PEFR) and if it's 50-70% of the personal best then administer the medication. If the PEFR is within 80-100% then no intervention is needed besides having the child rest. If PEFR is below 50% child needs to go to the ER.
review.bacterial-meningitis: No longer contagious after 24 hours of antibiotic therapy.
review.psoriasis: Incidense is lowest in dark-skinned races. Emotional stress leads to execerbation. Hormonal changes such as menopause could lead to excerbations of prorisasis.
review.activities-of-daily-living: Bathing, dressing, feeding and toileting. Assess the clients ablity to perform these tasks and basic hygine tasks like combing hair and brushing teeth.
review.hip-replacement: Client needs to have the leg abducted to prevent hip displacement. Avoid internal rotation of the leg.
review.immobility: Increases the excretion of calcium due to bone breakdown and increases the risk for renal calculi.
review.poor-apetite: Avoid giving client fluids before meals to prevent the feeling of fullness. Consult with a registered diatician to select special foods.
review.peripherally-inserted-central-catheter: Should be flushed with a push-pause technique with 10 ml of normal saline. This causes turbulence within the lumen which removes debris and reduces chances of the line clotting.
review.evacuation: Stable and ambulatory clients are the first to be evacuated, without a contagious disease. Levels of evacuation: Shelter in place - cease all routine activity and actively prepare for threat. Clinets, visitors and staff remain where they are. Staff provide initial protection from fire and smoke by closing doors and windows. Horizontal - move away from the incident ont the same floor Vertical - evacuate the entire floor, at least 2 floors from the incident if possible.
review.urinary-catheter: 1. Wash hands. 2. Gather supplies 3. Position client 4. Open the catheter kit 5. Don sterile gloves. 6. Open sterile solutions and swabs 7. Attach the syringe to cather 8. Test the balloon 9. Pick a non-dominant hand to be non-sterile. 10. Open the meatus 11. Clean the meatus, keeping the dominant hand sterile 12. Lubricate the catheter 13. Insert the catheter into the meatus 14. When urine appears in tubing, inflate the balloon. 15. Secure the catheter.
review.potassium-rich-foods: Dried appricots - 380mg Banana - 420mg Lima beans - 480mg Orange juice - 500mg Salmon - 530mg Sweet potato - 540mg Tomato paste - 670mg Prune juice - 710mg Potato - 940mg
review.pacing: If the client is pacing then give them a simple repetitive activity to do that is less exhausing.
review.neonatal-jaundice: Cause is breakdown of excessive red blood cells after birth. Not present at birth but begin 24 hours after. Total serum bilirubin will rise during the first few days, peaking at day 5 and declining after. Jaundice may be noted in the sclera and skin. Photoherapy is considedred when bilirubin is at or greater than 15 mg/dL at 72 hours of age.
